required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Peripheral Nerve Responses to Focal Vibration and Implications in Pain and Mobility for Patients With Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy
clinical_study.official_title: Peripheral Nerve Responses to Focal Vibration and Implications in Pain and Mobility for Patients With Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to characterize the changes in peripheral nerve functions (sensory and motor) in patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy, and examine the relations between the changes in nerve functions and changes in pain and mobility using focal vibration.

detailed_description.textblock: Peripheral nerve impairments are highly prevalent in patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) and are associated with pain and poor mobility. While peripheral sensorimotor nerve function is implicated in neuropathy, the mechanism associated with both pain and mobility is not well understood. Even less understood is the interplay between, and responses to, sensory and motor fibers of the affected peripheral nerve. In our previous study, focal vibration (FV) was effective in reducing pain and improving mobility for only a subgroup of participants with DPN. Because FV stimulates both motor and sensory peripheral nerve fibers, when combined with nerve conduction testing, it offers a unique opportunity to study both the sensory and motor peripheral nerve performance and their contribution to pain and mobility in patients with DPN. We are proposing a single group, repeated measured study to: characterize the changes in sensory and motor peripheral nerve functions; examine the association(s) between these changes and changes in pain and mobility, using FV. If successful, this study will provide us with a better understanding of the role played by sensory and motor nerve impairments in pain and mobility for DPN, and support larger clinical studies to optimize nerve function performance and the FV parameters. We will also explore how changes in the peripheral nerve function associate with severity of DPN.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: A 6-week, single group, repeated measures with double baselines research design to characterize the changes in sensory and motor nerve performance in DPN, and examine the relations between these changes and changes in pain and mobility

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline CMAP measures every 2 weeks for up to 6 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The peroneal compound muscle action potential (CMAP)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline NCV measures every 2 weeks for up to 6 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The peroneal motor nerve conduction velocity

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline SNAP measures every 2 weeks for up to 6 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The digital sensory nerve action potentials

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline BPI-DPN scores every 2 weeks for up to 6 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The Brief Pain Inventory Short Form for Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline TUG scores every 2 weeks for up to 6 weeks
Change from Baseline NTSS-6 scores every 2 weeks for up to 6 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The Neuropathy Total Symptom Score - 6-items (NTSS-6), which quantifies frequency and intensity of aching, burning, prickling and lancinating pain, numbness, and allodynia in patients' feet and legs.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline NSS scores every 2 weeks for up to 6 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The Neuropathy Symptom Score (NSS), which quantifies symptoms of motor, sensory, and autonomic deficits.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline NIS scores every 2 weeks for up to 6 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The Neurologic Impairment Score (NIS), composed of a sensory sub-score (which evaluates sensory perceptions to touch, prickling pain, vibration, joint position, and 1- and 10-g monofilaments in the upper and lower extremities) and a motor sub-score (which evaluates cranial nerves, muscle strength, muscle wasting, and deep tendon reflexes in the upper and lower extremities).

arm_group.description: The Myovolt device used in our previous study will be used for focal vibration delivery during week three to six. Participants will wear Myovolt secured by an elastic band, at a location based on therapist and participants preference. During the four weeks of the FV therapy, participants will be asked to use the Myovolt device for up to 0.5-hour per session (each site 10 minutes per session, with one-minute intersession between sites), once in the morning and once in the evening each day, for five days a week. The dosing paradigm was chosen based on the safety and potential effectiveness of the FV therapy, and our preliminary study.

intervention.description: Myovolt delivers vibration with a frequency between 60-300 Hz, and acceleration force between 1.8g to 19.1g peak to peak. Myovolt intensity will be set to ~up to 2X the participant's initial Myovolt perception threshold (however, the maximum intensity will be limited to 19.1g which is the maximum intensity the device can deliver). If the stimulation does not feel strong, the participant will be asked to manually increase the intensity until it feels strong but comfortable.

facility.name: College of Allied Health, University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center

reference.citation: Rippetoe J, Wang H, James SA, Dionne C, Block B, Beckner M. Improvement of Gait after 4 Weeks of Wearable Focal Muscle Vibration Therapy for Individuals with Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy. J Clin Med. 2020 Nov 22;9(11). pii: E3767. doi: 10.3390/jcm9113767.

Chandrashekhar R, Wang H, Dionne C, James S, Burzycki J. Wearable Focal Muscle Vibration on Pain, Balance, Mobility, and Sensation in Individuals with Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy: A Pilot Study. Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2021 Mar 2;18(5). pii: 2415. doi: 10.3390/ijerph18052415.

patient_data.ipd_description: The de-identified data might be shared with permission from the funder and PI per request.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: After completion of the 6 weeks study
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Only de-identified data will be shared with permission from the funder and PI per request
